docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes Morton County Sheriff Dept in North Dakota for escalating their tactics against American Indians and their allies protesting Dakota Access oil pipeline; expresses concern situation will not end well if Pres Obama does not step in and pressure authorities to stand down.

docs.snippet: A Kaiser Health Tracking Poll shows that support for health care reform moved upwards in September, particularly among Republicans....
docs.lead_paragraph: In my Saturday column I posited that President Obama's rope-a-dope tactic of letting Republican opponents tire themselves out during their summer of shouting may have worked better than many suspected.
docs.abstract: A Kaiser Health Tracking Poll shows that support for health care reform moved upwards in September, particularly among Republicans.

docs.snippet: Senator Barack Obama's sweeping get-out-the-vote effort in Ohio helped Democrats win two Congressional seats long held by Republicans, and seize control of the Ohio House for the first time since 1994.     About twice as many Ohioans said, after v...
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama's sweeping get-out-the-vote effort in Ohio helped Democrats win two Congressional seats long held by Republicans, and seize control of the Ohio House for the first time since 1994. About twice as many Ohioans said, after voting, that they had been contacted by an Obama volunteer urging their vote as said they had been contacted by a McCain supporter. That advantage helped Mr. Obama win Ohio's electoral votes, which went to George W. Bush in 2000 and 2004.
docs.abstract: Democrats Steven Driehaus and Ralph Regula win Ohio Congressional elections; Republicans maintain majority in State Senate; Barack Obama wins state, 51-47 percent; tally (S)

docs.snippet: As the economic crisis reshaped the presidential race in early October, Senator John McCain abandoned his campaign in Michigan, a state where he had spent $8 million on advertisements and had made repeated appearances.     That decision might have...
docs.lead_paragraph: As the economic crisis reshaped the presidential race in early October, Senator John McCain abandoned his campaign in Michigan, a state where he had spent $8 million on advertisements and had made repeated appearances. That decision might have affected Republican candidates farther down the ticket, as Democrats won close House contests against Republican incumbents, giving Democrats an 8-to-7 edge in the state's delegation. Representative Joe Knollenberg, an eight-term Republican, lost to Gary Peters, a Democrat and former state lottery commissioner, in the Detroit suburbs. Jack Kevorkian, the so-called suicide doctor, won more than 9,000 votes.
docs.abstract: Democrat Gary Peters defeats incumbent Republican Joe Knollenberg in Michigan Congressional election; Democrat Mark Schauer defeats incumbent Republican Tim Walberg; Democratic incumbent Sen Carl Levin retains his seat over wide field of challengers; voters pass ballot initiative to legalize medical marijuana and another to loosen restrictions on stem cell research; Barack Obama wins state, 57-41 percent; tallies (S)
